examples: the fore and hind pairs of wings

noun.description: The front part of something, especially a ship.

exclamation.description: Called out as a warning to people in the path of a golf ball.

phrases: his persistent effort brought this issue to the fore
They are brought to the fore only on rare occasions like when you make a trip back home.
It is important that we not only recognise but celebrate our heritage and this is just way of bringing it to the fore.
At no time in history has the issue of human rights come to the fore as in the current era.
Already the Italian has ridden to the fore in major World Cup races in the current campaign.
origin: Old English (as a preposition, also in the sense before in time, previously): of Germanic origin; related to Dutch voor and German vor. The adjective and noun represent the prefix fore- used independently (late 15th century).
